What we think of as the most mind-shatteringly macro end of the universe is actually the most mind-shatteringly micro end from a different perspective. We observe the vastness of the universe and the tinyness of quantum mechanics and perceive ourselves to be somewhere in the middle. But I feel as if there really is no end to the spectrum, observe the universe from even farther out and it's the brain of a lifeform who feels insignificant in the vastness of the universe they can see, and in the opposite direction, the subatomic particles we observe are actually galaxies full of life.

The universe (observable) is large indeed. But it pales in comparison to quantum microverse. It's like a mega-multiverse in it's own right that far exceeds in quantities and numbers than even the largest universe we could hope to discover.
Not to mention the quantum world is the only world that can defy any known laws of physics, thermodynamics and even reality itself. While I find astronomy and astrophysics astonishing, the world of the quanta is beyond anything we can begin to comprehend. Even the best scientific theories are extremely loose speculations at best. We'll know everything there is to know about the universe(s) before we even figure out how the very things that make it possible function on even a basic level.
How can you measure something that has no measurement? How can you quantify the unquantifiable, something that can and can't be and are both at the same time and everything in-between? That in my opinion is truly the mind boggling aspect of our existence. That might also hold the mystery of the elusive dark energy, matter, gravity, negative mass, anti-gravity and all the weird and freaky stuff we can see, measure some of them but know nothing about.

And yes, anti-gravity and negative mass do exist, without them wormholes and presumably even black holes couldn't form and exist. We just know nothing about how and where to look for it.

Okay, what we are calling blackholes under massive gravity are actually radio sources of x-rays and gamma rays and visible light.. On earth we do not need lots of gravity to make gamma and x-rays. All we need is an electric discharge like lightning or arc welders. So what we are seeing are probably not mathematically impossible black holes, but arcing between objects under electrical stress at the core, possibly busted up dense cores of stars or planets that busted up due to electrical stress.
Also, there is no evidence that elliptical galaxies are formed from other galaxies. They are usually wedged between two active galaxies like the low density B area between to current carrying wires. Elliptical galaxies have very little star formation or evidence of a core, like active galaxies have. So the evidence from elliptical galaxies alone shows that they probably do not form by smaller galaxies merging or they would have more massive cores, not the lack of a core. You need to do a little bit of research into Anthony Peratt and learn a bit about galaxies.
And, yes galaxies do seem to line up along electrical currents that connect them like beads on a string. And, yes the Hubble deep field did detect galaxies that , by current expansion theory, are much older than the theoretical age of the universe.

If galaxies keep colliding and getting bigger, and since gravity pulls objects together, will the universe eventually collide into one large mass? It was interesting to learn that the Milky Way and the Andromeda Galaxy are going to collide sooner or later and become the Milkomeda Galaxy. I’ve been taught what we call the “back-door policy”: when naming things you should think about if you’d be willing and able to shout it out the back door. I have realized that I am not willing to shout “MILKOMEDA” out my back door, so I began to come up with alternatives. I thought of Androway or Andray as new possibilities.
-Grace Linden 9th Grade

Néa Mitéra. Andromeda means “mindful of her husband” in Greek. I thought I’d go with a “mother’s milk” theme, with a bit less... traditional subtext. So I came up with Néa Mitéra, meaning “New Mother” in Greek. My first thought was Xanagenniméni Mitéra, meaning Reborn Mother, but that’s hard to pronounce or spell. Or remember.

In hindsight, Andromeda is a weird name choice given its etymology. Especially considering Andromeda wants us dead. Not the sort of mindfulness they had in mind, I bet.

Why not use the larger metric prefixes? The huge distances in astronomy would be a perfect fit for them applied to the metre.

Megametres for planet sizes (1Mm = 1000km, Earth is about 13Mm in diameter)
Gigametres for interplanetary distances (Earth is 150Gm from the sun)
Terametres for the outskirts of the solar system (light travels about 25Tm in a day)
Petametres for nearby stars (1Pm ~ 0.1ly)
Exametres for more distant stars (1Em ~ 100ly)
Zettametres for galactic sizes and nearby galactic distances (Milky way is about 1Zm wide, Andromeda is about 20Zm away)
Yottametres for anything bigger (1Ym ~ 105 million ly)

What other forces besides friction can cause the illumination in a quasar? And since these objects are billions of light years away, there's no way to know if there are still there or are still behaving like you described. They could have become extinct long ago, but the light that tells that story just hasn't shown up yet. Much like if i snail mail a letter to the farthest point away from my house on earth, and destroy my house the same day. When that letter arrives at its destination, the recipient would wrongly believe the source was still there.

We really need to invest in better propulsion technologies or AI machines that can go out and directly observe these things. This passive observation and 'cutting up' of the light that comes to us, is at best, too much of an educated guess and at the least, obsolete information due to the sources having changed or not even being there after the initial transmission of the light. But since our technology has not kept up with our ambition to penetrate deeper and further into space, keep using spectrophotomery and light dissection; passively observing and using esoteric math theories and hypothesis, a la Lawrence Kraus (something from nothing thinking, yea right).
